nodes.html: Mental health includes our emotional, psychological, and social well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act, and helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: Mental illnesses are disorders, ranging from mild to severe, that affect a person’s thinking, mood, and/or behavior. According to the National Institute of Mental Health, nearly one-in-five adults live with a mental illness.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: Many factors contribute to mental health conditions, including:

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Biological factors, such as genes or brain chemistry

nodes.html: • Anxiety disorders (including generalized anxiety, panic disorders, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), phobias, and social anxiety)

nodes.html: • Eating disorders (including Anorexia Nervosa, binge eating Disorder, and Bulimia Nervosa)

nodes.html: A Serious Mental Illness (SMI) is a mental illness that interferes with a person’s life and ability to function. Despite common misperceptions, having an SMI is not a choice, a weakness, or a character flaw. It is not something that just “passes” or can be “snapped out of” with willpower.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: View SAMHSA's Public Message about Serious Mental Illnesses.

nodes.html: Not sure if you or someone you know is living with mental health problems? Experiencing one or more of the following feelings or behaviors can be an early warning sign of a problem:

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Eating or sleeping too much or too little

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Pulling away from people and usual activities

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Smoking, drinking, or using drugs more than usual

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Feeling unusually confused, forgetful, on edge, angry, upset, worried, or scared

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Yelling or fighting with family and friends

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Experiencing severe mood swings that cause problems in relationships

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Having persistent thoughts and memories you can't get out of your head

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Hearing voices or believing things that are not true

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Inability to perform daily tasks like taking care of your kids or getting to work or school

nodes.html: Tips for Living Well with a Mental Health Condition

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: Having a mental health condition can make it a struggle to work, keep up with school, stick to a regular schedule, have healthy relationships, socialize, maintain hygiene, and more.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: However, with early and consistent treatment—often a combination of medication and psychotherapy—it is possible to manage these conditions, overcome challenges, and lead a meaningful, productive life.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: Today, there are new tools, evidence-based treatments, and social support systems that help people feel better and pursue their goals. Some of these tips, tools and strategies include:

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Stick to a treatment plan. Even if you feel better, don’t stop going to therapy or taking medication without a doctor’s guidance. Work with a doctor to safely adjust doses or medication if needed to continue a treatment plan.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Keep your primary care physician updated. Primary care physicians are an important part of long-term management, even if you also see a psychiatrist.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Learn about the condition. Being educated can help you stick to your treatment plan. Education can also help your loved ones be more supportive and compassionate.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Practice good self-care. Control stress with activities such as meditation or tai-chi; eat healthy and exercise; and get enough sleep.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Reach out to family and friends. Maintaining relationships with others is important. In times of crisis or rough spells, reach out to them for support and help.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Develop coping skills. Establishing healthy coping skills can help people deal with stress easier.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 9.2
Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86

nodes.html: • Get enough sleep. Good sleep improves your brain performance, mood and overall health. Consistently poor sleep is associated with anxiety, depression, and other mental health conditions.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 8.86
Element has sufficient color contrast of 7.2
Element has sufficient color contrast of 7.2

nodes.html: • To learn how to get support for mental health, drug, and alcohol issues, visit FindSupport.gov.

any.message: Element has sufficient color contrast of 7.2

nodes.html: • To locate treatment facilities or providers, visit FindTreatment.gov or call SAMHSA’s National Helpline at 800-662-HELP (4357).

nodes.html: • Stick to a treatment plan. Even if you feel better, don’t stop going to therapy or taking medication without a doctor’s guidance. Work with a doctor to safely adjust doses or medication if needed to continue a treatment plan.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Keep your primary care physician updated. Primary care physicians are an important part of long-term management, even if you also see a psychiatrist.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Learn about the condition. Being educated can help you stick to your treatment plan. Education can also help your loved ones be more supportive and compassionate.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Practice good self-care. Control stress with activities such as meditation or tai-chi; eat healthy and exercise; and get enough sleep.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Reach out to family and friends. Maintaining relationships with others is important. In times of crisis or rough spells, reach out to them for support and help.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Develop coping skills. Establishing healthy coping skills can help people deal with stress easier.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: • Get enough sleep. Good sleep improves your brain performance, mood and overall health. Consistently poor sleep is associated with anxiety, depression, and other mental health conditions.

any.message: List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element
List item has a <ul>, <ol> or role="list" parent element

nodes.html: Mental health includes our emotional, psychological, and social well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act, and helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Mental illnesses are disorders, ranging from mild to severe, that affect a person’s thinking, mood, and/or behavior. According to the National Institute of Mental Health, nearly one-in-five adults live with a mental illness.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Many factors contribute to mental health conditions, including:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html:
• Biological factors, such as genes or brain chemistry
  • Life experiences, such as trauma or abuse
  • Family history of mental health problems

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Biological factors, such as genes or brain chemistry

nodes.html: A Serious Mental Illness (SMI) is a mental illness that interferes with a person’s life and ability to function. Despite common misperceptions, having an SMI is not a choice, a weakness, or a character flaw. It is not something that just “passes” or can be “snapped out of” with willpower.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: View SAMHSA's Public Message about Serious Mental Illnesses.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: SAMHSA's Public Message about Serious Mental Illnesses

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Not sure if you or someone you know is living with mental health problems? Experiencing one or more of the following feelings or behaviors can be an early warning sign of a problem:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Eating or sleeping too much or too little

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Pulling away from people and usual activities

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Smoking, drinking, or using drugs more than usual

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Feeling unusually confused, forgetful, on edge, angry, upset, worried, or scared

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Yelling or fighting with family and friends

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Experiencing severe mood swings that cause problems in relationships

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Having persistent thoughts and memories you can't get out of your head

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Hearing voices or believing things that are not true

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Inability to perform daily tasks like taking care of your kids or getting to work or school

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Tips for Living Well with a Mental Health Condition

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Having a mental health condition can make it a struggle to work, keep up with school, stick to a regular schedule, have healthy relationships, socialize, maintain hygiene, and more.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: However, with early and consistent treatment—often a combination of medication and psychotherapy—it is possible to manage these conditions, overcome challenges, and lead a meaningful, productive life.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: Today, there are new tools, evidence-based treatments, and social support systems that help people feel better and pursue their goals. Some of these tips, tools and strategies include:

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Stick to a treatment plan. Even if you feel better, don’t stop going to therapy or taking medication without a doctor’s guidance. Work with a doctor to safely adjust doses or medication if needed to continue a treatment plan.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Keep your primary care physician updated. Primary care physicians are an important part of long-term management, even if you also see a psychiatrist.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Learn about the condition. Being educated can help you stick to your treatment plan. Education can also help your loved ones be more supportive and compassionate.

any.message: All page content is contained by landmarks
All page content is contained by landmarks

nodes.html: • Practice good self-care. Control stress with activities such as meditation or tai-chi; eat healthy and exercise; and get enough sleep.
